choices: unpack and settle in
check out the woods
1.content:
Krystal marveled at the rolling countryside, the huge red barns and cows, horses and chickens everywhere. She'd never seen so many trees, having been a city girl all her life, she was more accustomed to a few trees and alot of concrete and asphalt.

She looked at the directions the realtor had given her. The log cabin she had rented for the summer should be just around the next curve in the road. Yes, there was the mailbox with the rooster on it. She turned a sharp left and followed the gravel driveway for about a mile and there stood the cabin.

It was great! She opened the front door and went inside and her eyes could not believe such a marvelous place tucked into the woods. It had a good size living room with a rock fireplace and a cozy green overstuffed couch in front of it. That would make a great place to work on her novel, with her laptop cradled on her lap. It had french doors in back and all you could see were the woods. To the right was a small but efficient kitchen. It would serve her well, all she knew how to cook was tv dinners and microwave popcorn. Hopefully there would be some kind of diner in town.

Up the creaky wooden stairway was a bedroom and bathroom. The bathroom had a clawfoot bathtub, she'd always wanted to take a bath in one of those. The bedroom and bathroom was the whole length of the downstairs, so they were very roomy. The bedroom had a canopy bed with fabric draped around the top. There was a walkin closet and a huge desk. She sat down at the desk and thought it would be a great writing place also. She glanced out the window beside the desk and saw a dark figure staring up at the window. It looked like a man, but it was too far away, at the edge of the woods. Whatever it was jumped back into the darkness as soon as it was aware it had been seen. It unnerved her some but she knew she had her pistol and was quite capable of using it. Living in the city had taught her to always be prepared and self-defense was not just a class for fun.
1.title: Awww...the great outdoors!

choices: feel the hair on your neck rise
leave town quickly
11.content:
Krystal had unpacked and changed into her khaki shorts, bluejean shirt and her hiking boots and set out to look for the town and pick up some groceries. She came upon it and it looked like any other small town, with the town square, a grocery store, a hardware store, a feed store, the local diner, the VFW, where she learned from the grocer, held bingo on Saturday night, the gas station, and the picture show, as the young male gas station attendant told her, movies were only two dollars, but you wern't likely to see any of those Brad Pitt or Steven Segal movies. They were probably still showing Bob Hope and Bing Crosby movies, she thought as she loaded up her supplies into the back of her Jeep Grande Cherokee.

Well, she thought as she took one last look around town, the people were friendly enough, but there was something about them that she couldn't quite put her finger on. It seemed that only certain ones talked to her. The grocery store owner talked to her but not one of the cashiers had uttered a word, they just looked down and avoided her, and the young man stocking canned goods had totally run away when she was about to ask him a question. The same with the gas attendant, he had talked but the other two attendants had steered clear of her. Perhaps they were very shy people, still there was something there she could feel that was strange and eerie.
11.title: Trip to town

choices: decide to check out the area
111.content: Krystal put the last bag into the jeep and felt the hair rise on the back of her neck, she knew someone was watching her. She glanced up to the upstairs of a building across for the diner and saw the curtain fluttered as it quickly shut. Unknowingly she had put her hand on her purse where the pistol was.
111.title: Something strange is going on

choices: decide to get started on the novel
lock yourself in for the night
1111.content: Krystal headed out of town and drove through the countryside. She stopped at a fresh fruit and vegetable stand that was a stones throw away from the cabin she was renting. A handsome man, with dark curly hair and intense brown eyes was running the stand. He watched her with his thumbs clasped in his overalls, as she picked up the peaches and smelled them for freshness. She noticed his lack of a shirt under his bibs and his lean muscles underneath. She remembered she was there to pick fruit, not a man and told him she'd take a small basket of the peaches. His eyes darted around nervously as if he wanted to say something and then changed his mind. She handed him the money and couldn't help wondering what it was that was on his mind. His hands shook as he handed her the change and she looked at him pleadingly, to just tell her. He instantly turned around and started straightening the shelves of vegetables, completely ignoring her. She walked to her car and drove away.
1111.title: The day just gets stranger

choices: try to run
see if you remembered the gun
11111.content:
After putting the groceries away, Krystal popped her some popcorn and lay on the big couch munching away and watching the wildlife out in the yard and trees. Several rabbits hopped around and birds flitted around among the trees at the forest edge. She watched the rabbits as they froze and listened to something and the birds flew away to hide. She sat up and strained to see something, but pretty soon the rabbits relaxed and hopped away. She finished the popcorn and grabbed a fresh peach to eat.

She decided to get started on her novel right away, why the summer would be gone before she knew it! She climbed the stairs to the bedroom and set her laptop up on the desk. She wrote her cover page and started on the first chapter. Things were going pretty good, when she began to get very sleepy. Out of the corner of her eye, she saw a strange beam of light over the top of the forest, then another, then another. She'd never seen anything like it. She had to get a closer look at this, and she half stumbled down the stairs.

She stood on the back deck, marveling at the lights that had now took on strange colors, colors she had never seen before. They were drawing her to them and she felt the cool grass beneath her feet as she headed for the treeline. She was at the forest edge now, begginning to fight the tree limbs and find the strange lights when something or someone grabbed her by the arm and swung her around!
11111.title: All the pretty lights

choices: sleep like a baby
111111.content:
Krystal woke up and was startled to see that she was on the couch in the cabin's living room. Hadn't she just been in the wood's? Someone had grabbed her from behind and put their hand over her mouth, just before she passed out. And yet, here she was on the couch and according to her watch, a whole hour had passed. The smell of peaches was overwhelming, but she had wrapped her peach seed in plastic before she'd thrown it away. She started to think that it was all a bad dream, the trip had made her really tired or something.

She turned off the lamp and stood at the backdoor staring out at the woods. Nothing was out of the ordinary, but when she turned to go upstairs, the hairs on the back of her neck stood up again and a chill ran up her spine. She felt she was being watched again and hurried up the stairs and jumped into bed. She'd get a good nights sleep and get an early start on her novel. She just needed to relax and take it easy.
111111.title: Lights out!

choices: take a break from writing
1111111.content:
When Krystal finally did sleep, she slept like a baby. She woke up and felt so good, she decided to take a jog down the long driveway and pick up the paper from the previous evening. She jogged to the end of the driveway and retrieved the paper from the box. She was still jogging in place when the guy at the fruit stand caught her eye and she decided to go over and be friendly with one of the locals, after all he was so darn cute in those overalls and she'd like to get to know him better.

She watched for traffic and jogged across. He saw her coming and immediately went to straightening baskets and wiping down the countertop. She noticed that he'd look at her for a few minutes and then lower his eyes.

"Good morning, my name is Krystal, I don't believe I know your name yet and we really should know each other's names, I'm going to be here for the whole summer. You're peaches are the best I've ever tasted. I'll probably be buying alot of them.", she gave him her best smile and leaned on the counter.

"Oh yeah, the name is Boone. The peaches won't last much longer, as a matter of fact, this is the last basket of them and they are already spoken for.", he looked around nervously as he pushed a couple of baskets back under the skirt of the table, so that she could not see them.

Well, so much for that ploy, she thought, as she noticed him admiring her jogging shorts .

"Will you be selling anything else this season?", she asked him, looking dissapointed.

"Oh, well, we'll have the usual garden vegetables, you know cukes, squash, green beans....", he looked at her while also leaning on the counter.

He must have realized he was so close to her and he immediately jumped back away from the counter, looking about nervously again. Maybe he had something else on his mind, perhaps she'd come back another time, when he wasn't so preoccupied.

"Well Boone, I have to go now, I'll be back to get some of those vegetables.", she waved to him and jogged back across the street.

She looked back, when she was safely across the road and it looked as if Boone was in a trance or something, just standing there, staring at that last bucket of peaches. She spent the rest of the day working on her novel and enjoying the peacefulness of the woods, but the night was about to fall and it would be anything but peaceful.
1111111.title: Peace in the woods

choices: Run out the front door.
Accept Cheryl's hand and trust her.
11111111.content:
Krystal gazed thoughtfully out of the dining room window as the last few rays of sunlight filtered across the sky. The town wasn't so bad really. Sure the people were a bit weird but at least here she could devote her full attention to the novel. Krystal's mind drifted for several more minutes before being interrupted by a knock at the door.

"Come in, it's open!" Krystal called out.

There was only more knocking in response.

"I said it's open!"

As the knocking continued Krystal made her way to the front door while muttering something about "redneck hicks" under her breath. Upon opening the door, a small figure lunged at her legs and quickly took hold.

"Hey let go! I…"

Krystal stopped in mid sentence as the figure looked up at her. Now hugging her legs was a young girl, about 9 or 10 years old at the most. The child's short blond hair was tasseled and full of knots. Her skin was covered with small cuts and bruises, most likely from running though the woods. As Krystal closed the door the girl finally looked up at her with a set of red rimmed eyes.

"What's your name?" Krystal asked.

"Cheryl" The child replied weakly.

"Why are you way out here?" She said. "You're a long way from town."

"I…I can't…"

Suddenly she pushed herself away from Krystal and sunk to her knees. The child began to cry out in desperation filled voice while clutching at her head.

"Leave me alone!" Cheryl yelled. "Stop it! I…"

The young girl fell silent and slumped to the floor. Krystal rushed to her side and quickly took the child into her arms.

"Please, don't hurt me." Cheryl whimpered.

Krystal carefully set the young girl down on a nearby sofa. Covering her body with an old blanket that had hung over the side, Krystal tried to comfort the child as best as she could. It was at that moment that Krystal felt her fingers touch something cold on the back of Cheryl's neck. Bending her neck forward, Krystal gasped when she saw the object imbedded at the base of the child skull.

The object was no bigger than a dime and looked as though someone had cut a marble in half. The color was a deep yet translucent blue, which sparkled ever so often. Branching out from there was a hair thin strand of the same material the encompassed Cheryl's entire neck, much like a collar.

"What on earth?"

"A gift." Cheryl said in an overly calm voice.

Krystal moved back a bit as Cheryl sat up. The color had returned to her once horribly ashen face. Cheryl managed a brief smile before speaking.

"Your follies compound one atop another. Trapping yourselves in a perpetual living hell of your own making. Mankind's era of self-rule is at an end. Once you have been reborn through us is when you will know true peace."

"That doesn't make and sense." Krystal said in confusion. "I don't understand."

"Don't worry child. You will soon." Cheryl replied.

As Cheryl pushed the blanket aside and stood up, Krystal began to move away from her. Looking to the door, she thought about trying to run away. Suddenly her entire body tingled for a few moments and she couldn't help turning back towards the little girl.

"Run to where, Krystal?" Cheryl said. "To a world where compassion and kindness are viewed as nothing more than weaknesses? A world consumed with hate and ignorance? No, you belong here now…with me."

"Leave Cheryl alone!" Krystal nearly yelled. "She's just a child!"

"You think I want to hurt her?" Cheryl replied. "I just need to borrow her and the others like her for a while."

"Others?"

"Others like her…and you." Cheryl replied. "The kind, the innocent. Once I've rid this world of the hateful and cruel, people like you will be able to live as you should. Soon your soul will be intertwined with my own, you'll never be alone or frightened again."

Krystal felt her back bump into the wall. Cheryl seemed to sense the urgency in her actions. Lifting her hand, the little girl offered her palm to Krystal.

"Take my hand, Krystal." Cheryl said in a calming voice. "Take it and I can show you things you could never even begin to imagine."

"No, I can't" Krystal stuttered fearfully.

Krystal didn't have many options and she knew it. The pistol was in a cabinet at the other end of the room. Even if she reached she wasn't sure she could bring herself to shoot a child. The Front door was nearby but it was pitch black out side and running around in the dark didn't sound like a very good idea at the moment.

Suddenly the sound of footsteps came from outside. Cheryl turned and looked at the door for a moment and then back at Krystal.

"Please, make this easy on yourself." Cheryl said. "It's only a matter of time anyway. You can't escape your fate now…only accept it."
11111111.title: Encounter

hope its not that creepy child

Krystal ran out the front door past the child who wanted her to join her in whatever wierd thing that was happening to her.

She ran to the forest and was dodging tree limbs and huge rocks. She began running down hill and tripped and scraped up her knees and made them bleed. She ducked behind a boulder when she heard the trucks approaching, but they were not government vehicles, merely the farmers big grain and vegetable trucks. As she was peeking over the top of the boulder for a better look, again something grabbed her from behind!

The person who grabed Krystal had very strong hands. 'It must be a man.' she thought. But the thought was ripped out of her head as the man pulled her very ruffly backwords makng her stumble over stones, twigs, and holes.
As she stumbled and fell she hopped to God that she was not going to be murdered. Soon the unleavel foriste floor changed to a cold, smooth one.
The man then opened a heavy door by the sound and thowe her in side a very small smelly stone room. THen he slamed the door.

1111111111.title: In to the cell.

choices: Grab the child and face your captors
Pretend to be unconcious
11111111111.content:
The dank, musty atmosphere of Krystal's holding cell reminded her of the medieval dungeons she had been fascinated with as a young teenager; her early studies of King Arthur and Sir Gawain & the Green Knight, The Musketeers and the infamous Man in the Iron Mask, and her favorite hero/heroine Joan of Arc, had instilled in her a burning desire to storytell and a vivid imagination to harbor and feed the flame. A talented and imaginative scribe, she was heralded by her mentors, yet shunned by her peers.

Her grade school days had given her the strength to succeed in her adult life and had hardened her inner shell and conviction. Self-esteem was sometimes questioned, but her self-respect and dedication to herself and her dreams saw her through those hard times. They prepared her for the here and now. She didn't have a clue where here was, but she definitely needed to draw upon her inner-strength now.

"Keep a cool head, girl," she whispered to herself. The almost inaudible tone was answered by a soft, shaken voice a few dark feet away.

"Sh-sh-shhh," the meager voice responded. She turned abruptly to her left, surprised by the sudden, timid response. "Th-th-ththey don't l-l-like wh-when you s-s-sp-speak," it answered back, stuttering uncontrollably and obviously frightened. Because of the hurried, broken words, she could not tell if her cellmate was male or female, but it was obviously a child.

"I'm here sweety, don't be afraid," she pleaded to the child and held out her hand trying to both comfort and console. The child couldn't have been more than ten feet away, but her eyes had yer to adjust to her pitch black surroundings.

Sensing her advancing presence, the child scurried away, further lengthening the distance between them.

"Don't be afraid, I'm not gonna hurt you," said Krystal. "I only want to help. I'm gonna get us both out of here," she said coaxingly, not knowing when or how she would do it.

"P-p-p-pl-pleassse d-don't talk. Th-they'llll c-come."

The stillness of the room was interrupted by the sound of a heavy steel door creaking open, the darkness pierced by a soft-glowing bulb atop the stoned staircase down the vast hall.

"T-t-t-too l-l-late," the child began to whimper.
11111111111.title: Unwelcomed Company

choices: Krystal finds a tube in her pocket.
Boon appears!
111111111111.content:
Panic seized her. She ran into the darkest corner of the room with the child and waited in utter silence. A figure clothed head to toe in white entered. As Krystal smelled it - a strange, terrible odor, something like rotten innards masked with the sickly scent of bananas - a dread overcame her. She felt the child shaking beside her.

Krystal suddenly couldn't stand it anymore. She grabbed the child and stood up. "Who are you?" she said loudly, with as much hostility as she could manage.

"N-n-n-nooo," whimpered the child. "L-l-let me go!!" It wrestled out of her grip and disappeared into the darkness once again, leaving Krystal alone to face the silent figure, who had angled his head in an odd manner staring at her.

"We have been watching you, Krystal," came a synthesized, silky voice from the suit. "That man, Boone, led you to us. We are so glad you finally made it."

She was so terrified that the whites of her eyes showed. She backed up. "No! Stay away from me, you - you creep!"

The figure advanced, reaching out his arm. "Come to me, Krystal. I will not harm you. You are safe with me."

"No, I'm not. Leave me alone! Don't touch me!"

Behind her, the child began to keen. Krystal tried to kung-fu the white-figured creature but it only grabbed hold of her ankle and began dragging her out of the room. At a steady, mechanical pace he pulled her out, even though she twisted and screamed and clutched at the nubbly ground. In the hall outside several more white figures appeared and swarmed her and began carrying her up the stairs.

Krystal heard through the walls a loud steady chant. "Kry-stal. Kry-stal. We-want. Kry-stal."
111111111111.title: Grab the child and face your captors

choices: Continue looking for the door.
Rush the chair and demand answers.
11111111112.content:
Krystal slapped aside the hand and leapt to her feet. Quickly moving across the small dimly lit room she reached the spot where she was sure the door should be. The wall was a smooth metallic substance, and she ran her hands across it trying to find the seam of the way out.
Her heart was pounding in her temples as she frantically looked for the way out. Her breathing was getting ragged as her searching hands found nothing but the smoothness of the wall.
"Please my dear," a weak voice said. "Please sit down I certainly cannot harm you."
A small electric whir came to her ears, and she turned slowly as a small, decrepit looking figured in an electric wheel chair moved into the light. The figure in chair appeared to be an extremely old man. The skin of his face and hands withered and looked like it would fall off his bones. What little hair he had left was white and disheveled, like it hadn't been combed in months. What caught Krystals' attention were his eyes. The blue eyes of the only other person she could sense were clear, and bright. The apparent life and intelligence in those eyes gave a lie to this figures apparent frailty.
11111111112.title: The Room

choices: Enter it.
Go back to the man.
111111111121.content:
Krystal had to get out of the strange place. Now. She couldn't trust the odd, old man. Who knows what he could (or would) do to her... Probably not much. He looked very weak and feeble. It wasn't as if he was a monster or something.

Krystal stared at his eyes again. So blue... So bright... Something seemed mysteriously familiar about them.

"I'm sorry, sir," replied Krystal, her voice shaking. "I-- I... don't trust you."

At first, Krystal nervously, slowly stepped away from him. The man just gazed at her with his clever eyes, not saying anything. It made her uncomfortable.

"Um, well-- I'll be going then..." Krystal stammered, voice quivering. Then she dashed off through the narrow hall, looking for an exit.

"Aha!" announced Krystal to herself, coming to a halt. She found a door!
111111111121.title: Strange Place

1111111111211.content:
Krystal barges into the room and then you scream in horror.

She is in a large mirrored room. In the center of the room is a thin blond athletic build strapped to a chair with a tube in her mouth. One of the aliens near her presses a button and a strange fluid begins to come down the tube and fill her mouth. Krystal watches as her rock hard abs begins to turn into soft flab. She grows fatter and fatter she tries to scream and tears run down her plumping cheeks as her now double chin turns into a triple her thighs rub together. She cries some more. She is taken off the chair and led to a row of other fat girls like her where cups are attached to her breasts and milk starts to flow.

The Aliens were turning females into COWS!

The girls cry as they eat from a trough and the aliens poke and laugh at their large bodies shaking their flab and snapping pictures for their studies.

She watched as another cow that was not making milk was slowly walked into another room.

Screaming wasn't Krystal's brightest idea but she was now captured as two Aliens dragged her over to the chair.
1111111111211.title: Cows! They're turning us into Cows!

choices: Awake to the forest around you.
Awake back in the city, in your appartment, the alarm clock going off.
1111111111212.content:
Reaching for the gold-plated handle, Krystal's skin crawled at the thought of the man, the decrepit old bright-eyed man, staring at the back of her head. Anticipating. Salivating...hungry. Halfway through spinning the cool metal bulb she stopped.

"Go ahead," he intoned, too-gentlemanly. "As I have already told you, young one, there is not a thing I can do about it." A smile that did not lighten his eyes (those magnificent eyes!) as it should opened his mouth.

Krystal took her surroundings into consideration and cursed at herself for her hastiness. The room had only one door. White washed walls, bleached of color and texture, surrounded the shellac sated concrete flooring that was shaped in an almost perfect square. Disheveled pulses of fear caught in her throat as she realized she had been brought here, she had not been invited and she had not come under her own power. She released the door handle, the resounding click of the latch sounded back to her off the walls of the bare room a few times then died out.

The man's smile faded, slowly and uncontrollably, and a snarl lifted the corner of his lip. His eyes - which to Krystal looked like they belonged in a dolls head and not a living and breathing man - were partially covered as his eyelids narrowed to squint.

"I never wanted to be here in the first place."

Blue-eyes's sneer turned vicious, and for all the 'old' man's claims that he could not hurt her in any physical way, he leapt out of the mock wheel chair with the ferocity of a lion.

Krystal gasped as he closed the distance incredibly fast - too fast for a mortal (and after the day's events she should not have expected any less) - then snagged her arm with a mighty and muscular hand. Krystal felt the deep burning sensation of pressure chocking the blood out of her arm, but it was the man's arms that shocked her more than anything.

No longer deformed, no longer pocked with sunspots or struggling hairs and flaccid skin. Taught, tan and veiny, the monsters hand spun her around, much as in the forest - it must be the same one - and she squeaked in spite of her efforts to gag the reflex of fear. Boone bore back at her with eyes of iron.

"Boone?"

"This could have been a lot easier." He slammed his muscular hand into her head.

Thudding dully, Krystal was surprised there was no pain. Lying on the cool hard floor, the light in the room - which she realized she could not see the source, it seemed the whole room glowed of its own accord - muted, though she did not think Boone had moved the dimmer switch to set the mood.

She could see Boone's tall form moving to the wheelchair again and she willed herself to move, but her body did not respond. She looked down to her checkered slip-ons, criss-crossed with mauve and pink. She always thought they went so well with her fuchsia skirt she wore now, and her thick black sweater top. She thought Boone might have liked it as she left the cabin this morning.

"Why didn't you just walk through the door like everybody else?"

She could not respond, even if she wanted to, as a coin shaped object, similar to the one on Cheryl's neck, dropped in front of her face on the floor.

His bright blue menacing eyes appeared in front of her face and his breath smelled like peaches. "Its always easier if you just go through the door."
1111111111212.title: The wrong door?

choices: Joe, the lawyer to the rescue
Joe, the lawyer, is in on it...or is he?
11111111112122.content:
Shrill incessant beeping wedged its way into her thoughts, dark and nauseous - ugly meanderings into the meaning of life when faced with the reality of death - as Krystal pulled herself from the latest late-night-out.  Her head throbbed with the leftovers of strong drink - it must be - and she still could not open her left eye.  It wasn't until she swiped her hand across it that she felt the sharp line of hurt her hand caused and remembered - it wasn't a dream! - the Bright-eyed farmer, evil and not at all human, forcing his hand into her head.  



          In a rush the nights events tumbled down on her like a landslide.  Boone, appearing in the place of the old man, his strong, muscular hand holding her tight and rendering her helpless in that strange room.  The room with no lights, and it was not daytime, that seemed to glow all on it's own.  A CULT!  She thought angrily....   I moved to a Bloody Stepford Wifes community! 



          She rubbed her palms over her head again and then started to sweat.  How did I get back to my appartment, all the Way to New York?  The implications were dizzying.  They somehow knew where she lived...and if they knew where she lived...what else did they know?   



          Krystal leapt out of bed, crumpling the bedsheets to the floor in a heap and abashedly realized she was not wearing any clothes.  Those bastards!  She knew nothing had happened.  She could feel that much, but the fact that that creep Boone had done this to her was humiliating.  And she was not used to being disgraced like that.  



          She grabbed her red-satin robe from the hook behind the bathroom door and swung it onto her shoulders.  She found her purse on the wooden chair next to that, placed with care - I would have preferred it to be strewn across the room, instead of placed there with care - that just made it feel more of a violation.  



          Dismissing the thought as soon as she could she rifled through her black-scaled purse and found her phone.  Speed-dialing her lawyer she headed into the bathroom.  



          What she saw made her gasp.  

          Her once beautiful face, soft and kind was swollen and bruised, like a battered woman on news, like the elephant-man.  

          "Oh, God..." she breathed, hardly hearing the response on the other end.

          "Krystal, is that you?"  The hollow male voice on the other end of the line was trying to get her attention but she could hardly pull the strength to answer.  

          "Joe...oh, Joe...something horrid has happened to me, can you come over?"

          "To your place...thought you were in writer's heaven?"

          "Joe," she breathed.  "Please."

          "Okay, okay.  I will be right over, do you need me to bring anything?"

          "Cigarettes, and whatever strong you have to drink."

          "Wow.  That bad, huh?  How long has it been since you quit?"

          "Not for me, you are going to need it..." she hardly could speak as she reached around with her free hand to the back of her neck.  A cool metalic coin was at the base of her neck - why not? - "And I guess it wont hurt me either."



          She pressed the end button and leaned over the sink and grimaced.  She was going to throw up.   As she headed to the toliet, as she wretched horribly, she did not know that she was being watched.  But not from afar, from inside of the room, with fleshly eyes, peering from inside of the wall...hungry....knowing....Blue....
11111111112122.title: Awake back in the city, in your appartment, the...

Who is Cheryl?

"I'd rather stand, thanks very much", said Krystal. She had been fooled by Cheryl once. She wasn't going to be fooled again.
"Very well". The man sighed. "What do you want to know?"
111111111122.title: Sit Down...

Krystal freaks out and tries to force the door open
1111111111221.content:
"Are you an alien?", Krystal asked the man.
He answered her question in a strange voice that seemed weary with age, "Am I an alien? No. Am I human? No. You don't seem to understand, but then, how can you possibly be expected to? With all of the things on television now, with all of the science in your world, you drift further and further away from the truth."
Krystal spoke, confused and terrified, "What are you then?"
The man answered, in his aged and raspy voice, "I am older than the stars, a force that has always been here and will always remain. I and my people are trying to bring you salvation, but you seem so desperate to turn it away."
Krystal spoke, unaware that her voice was trembling now, "Are-are you an angle?"
The man shook his head and gave a weak laugh, "No, of course not. I am a flesh and blood creature, just like you."
Krystal asked, now full of terror, "Then what are you?"
The man replied, "Not even I know the answer to that question. Only one does."
Krystal was shaking as she asked, "One-one what?"
The man smiled and said, "Only you know, Krystal, only you."
1111111111221.title: Older than the stars

choices: Return to town and beg for help.
Get in your car and drive as far away as possible.

"How..how do you know my name?" Krystal demanded.
"Oh we know much more about you then your name." The man replied. He tried to say it gently but Krystal got pale and slowly backed up. "Krystal, we need you don't you understand. You can help us and we can help you, together we can bring your peace to your species."
"What kind of peace," yelled Krystal with a sudden rush of courage. "The one where your laying in a coffin!"
"Krystal!" the man called but Krystal was already running through the door.
11111111112211.title: Krystal asks how he knows her name

choices: figure out how to save the world
leave this to professionals
1111111112.content:
She really hoped it wasn't that creepy child! She heard a voice in her ear telling her to please be quiet or they would kill the both of them. She nodded her head to them that she would and was released.

She turned around and saw Boone kneeling behind her.

"What the heck is going on around here?", she whispered to him.

"There was a creepy little girl at my house and she had something in her neck. I don't know about you, but in my home town, that would be considered to be very strange!", she winced at her bleeding, scraped up knees.

"It's a lot going on around here, and I will tell you all about it.", he said as he took a strange glowing rod out of his pocket."Just as soon as we take care of your injury."

Her eyes got very large as she looked at the object and he told her it was alright and for some reason she believed him. He waved the rod toward her knees and all signs of injury were gone and completely healed up.

"Ok Boone, now I'm really scared because we don't have that kind of technology here on Earth yet, do we?", she stared at him and then looked at her knees again.

"No Krystal, this is not from Earth, but it's ok, cause I'm not one of them, I happened to steal this from the alien I disposed of.", he said in a matter of fact tone.

"Alien? Oh my God! I was thinking maybe that the government was doing some strange experiments or something."

"Well, you're half right. There are some government officials that are running the show with the aliens, but the rest of the world doesn't know about it, certainly not the President or FBI, or the CIA, that I know of anyway.", he looked afraid as the strange lights that she'd seen the night before appeared.

"I saw those lights last night. I walked to the edge of the woods to see them, it was like they were calling to me, and thats all I remembered when I woke up on the couch. I thought it must have been a dream."

"It wasn't a dream. You ate one of the peaches didn't you? They make the farmers grow the peaches laced with their mind inhibitors. This enables them to call you to them, reducing the stress of them having to come after you. I brought you back from the woods the other night, and when you didn't show up, they sent the child after you.", he settled back against the rock and watched the colored lights."I shouldn't have sold them to you but they watch us."

"The peaches?!? You were the one who put me on the couch and the strong odor of peaches was from you."

They heard voices, the trucks had stopped. They peeked over the top to see people being removed from the trucks and they looked as if they were in a trance. Once they were removed, they just stood there untill some people in white lab coats came out of a building and got them and herded them inside. She looked back to Boone.

"Mostly out of towners...they put the peaches at all the local motels around here and they go into a trance and start walking here and the trucks just stop and pick them up on the way. Then they take them in there...", he looked at the building and just stared at it for a minute. "They took most of my family there and I couldn't do anything to stop them! They put those things in their neck and it's all over, the spaceships come and get them and who knows what they do with them!", he looked sadly at her.

"Oh Boone you"ve saved me and we'll figure out how to stop this!"
1111111112.title: Aliens!???!!

choices: figure out a plan
11111111121.content:
Krystal peeked over the rock again and then sat back down, the hard edges of the rock digging into her backbone.

"We've got to get in there Boone, if we knew what was going on in there, we may be able to help those people or get them some help."

"How are we gonna get in there? That's crazy!", he shook his head in amazement, that she would even consider such a ludicrous idea." Even if we did get in there, we'd be on our own because we don't even know who in the government we can trust."

"You're right about that, but we've got to try, we can't just walk away and let these....beings take our people and do whatever it is they are doing with them!", she said taking his hands in hers and letting him know that she was afraid but also determined.
11111111121.title: Can't let them win

choices: being lead to slaughter?
111111111211.content:
"Alright, I'm with you.", Boone said trying not to show his fear."But I think you should know, that I used to work here."

"What???", she said, loudly and then quieter," You were one of those traitors, working side by side with those aleins???", she asked incredously.

"Now hold on, that was before I knew what went on in there and as soon as I learned just a fraction of what they were doing, I quit.", he bit his lip and fought back the tears,"That's when they took my family, so I wouldn't tell anyone. I wanted to tell you those times at the fruit stand, but I don't know who I can trust, they're always watching me."

" I'm sorry for your family, but your working there could be to our advantage, since you know the inside. And it may be good for your family, since they are holding them hostage so you won't talk, they're probably still holding them here and didn't ship them off to some planet."

"You're right! I didn't think of that.", he said, now a small glimmer of hope on his face.

"Alright, I think when the next truck comes in, that we be ready. We'll stand at the back of the truck with the others and let them lead us inside. You stay close to me and once we're inside, we'll try to break away from the others.", she said, trying to convince herself that it could work.

"Sounds good. Once inside they herd them like cattle into a large room for screening and sorting.I know a place we can duck into. I can get us around a little but the restricted areas will be a bit harder.", he said as they heard the rumble of trucks again.

They waited till the last truck had stopped and ran to the back of the truck before the farmers or lab people came out. They stood close together among the others until they were lead away. Krystal looked blankly ahead and felt a tight knot building in her stomach.
111111111211.title: Join the herd

choices: find Boone's family
1111111112111.content:
Krystal was even more nervous as Boone kept getting farther and farther away from her. A large sliding door opened and they walked out of the bright sunlight and into the darkness of florescent lighting. It took her eyes awhile to adjust and she noticed that the lab people were putting people on a long conveyor belt, single file. She stepped onto the belt and was trying to look over everyone's head to look for Boone.

It looked as if they were reaching a large domed room and she caught something out of the corner of her eye. It was Boone, about three feet below the belt, standing on a metal platform. He motioned for her to jump and she did. He caught hold of her, grabbed her hand and ushered her through a metal door.They went up a flight of stairs and along a catwalk. They could see the fifty or so people below, being passed behind screens and being placed into groups.

"What's going on down there? What are those screens for?", she asked Boone.

"Those are intelligence screens, to put it simply, they only want the smart ones. How can they rule the Earth with dumb people? I'd like to show them how dumb I am!", he said with a hiss.

What about the groups?", she whispered.

"I'm not sure you want to hear that part.", he bowed his head and rested it on the metal railing, it felt cool on his hot face.

"Tell me. I have to know everything. I want to get mad, so I can get even! I may be a dumb earthling to them, but I may have a few good tricks up my sleeve.", she countered.

"The small group of five, as you know, are the most intelligent, they will stay here, be programmed and be infiltrated into government positons so they can change any legislature that doesn't suit them. Some will be higher up officials in the law enforcement, so large numbers of people dissapearing will not be reported, those files will mysteriously dissapear too, no questions asked. The middle group there, not intelligent enough to use here on Earth, will be shipped to their planet, to be used for slaves, in their homes, workplaces, etc., until they get old.", he sucked in air and started to continue.

"And the older group of people down there?", she asked slowly, looking at the group of senior citizens, reminding her of her gentle grandparents back home.

"I'm afraid they will be used for, to put it mildly, a food source."

She covered her mouth as she gasped and thought of her own grandparents as alien food. She slid down the metal railing and sat there on her knees, thinking she might be sick but the feeling passed. Boone put his arm around her shoulder and she turned and layed her face against his chest.

"Those are awful things you've had to live with Boone. Lets find your family."
1111111112111.title: Screening and Grouping

choices: face what she's done
11111111121111.content:
Krystal and Boone continued along the catwalk until they came to another metal door. This one was more secure and required a sequence of numbers to be punched in. Boone just had to remember the sequence, but the stupid thing just kept buzzing. Afraid someone might hear the noise, he took a moment to think back, search his memory for the numbers. He tried again and they heard a whoosh and the door swung open.

Boone led the way down a narrow hallway and ushered Krystal into a room at the end of the hall. He handed her white lab clothes and grabbed some himself. They put them on over their clothing and checked to make sure no one was coming before they went back out into the hall again to yet another door.

"This is where it gets a little hairy because there are more people wandering around up here.", Boone told her in a hushed tone. "Just act like we belong and I don't think anyone will bother us." He pushed open the door and they walked cautiously but steady down the hall. Now people, also in lab coats, were passing them in the hall, hardly without a glance.

They now had to get in an elevator to ride down to the lower level. Boone was convinced his family could be located in the G sector, which was two levels below ground. He'd never been down that far and he really wasn't sure they could get that far, it was probably pretty secure.

The doors opened and they got off the elevator and Boone was leading the way. Krystal saw the back of Boone's neck and what looked like the strange thing that was in the girl's neck. She took the pistol from her waistband and pointed it in his direction.

He must have felt something was wrong, because he turned around and looked at her with eyes that were shocked to see a gun in her hands.

"Krystal don't!", he shouted, but she fired off two shots and he jumped at the reverberating sound.
11111111121111.title: Friend or enemy?

choices: run for all your worth
111111111211111.content:
Boone watched in horror as Krystal pointed the gun at him and fired the shots and he closed his eyes as his ears rang from the explosion. She lowered the gun and stood there shaking.

Boone soon noticed that he wasn't shot and turned around to where Krystal was staring. There was a dead alien laying on the floor behind him oozing purple fluid all over the floor.

"I didn't know if it would kill it or not, but it was worth a try.", she said relieved and handed the gun over to him.

"God, I thought you were gonna kill me, that I was one of them!", he took the gun and ran a hand through his hair in relief and held the gun down by his side.

"Boone, even I wasn't fooled by that thing you've glued to your neck, really!", she laughed nervously, not really believing what she'd just done.

"Well, can't blame me for trying.", he said just as an alarm started to sound. "There's the alarm. They know there's been a breach of security. We've got one chance to make it to G sector and that's if we get to one of the hydropods before they catch us. C'mon." He tucked the gun in his waistband and grabbed Krystal's hand. They were still alive so far, they had a chance.
111111111211111.title: Die you alien!

choices: do they make it out of the complex?
do they get caught?
1111111112111111.content:
Boone grabbed Krystal's hand and pulled her down the hallway. He stopped at each door checking the knobs to see if they were locked. Finding one that was open, they ducked in behind the door just in time as a patrol of military security ran past and continued on farther down the hallway. Opening the door a crack he looked and listened for the sound of running feet somewhere in the hallway, hearing none, he pulled her from the little supply closet that they had hidden in.
"Come on, this way" he said, as he pulled her back in the direction they had just came from.
They turned down other connecting hallways until Krystal was sure they were hopelessly lost.
"I sure hope you know where you're going" she whispered to him.
"If the lay out hasn't changed, yes" he said to reassure her.
Just as they went to turn another corner they heard the distinct sound of feet running in their direction. Boone pulled her back and they ducked into the corner of a recessed door. Trying the knob, it was locked. He pressed Krystal and himself up tight against the wall in hopes that they wouldn't be seen. They hadn't time to try for another door. Krystal held her breath and said a silent prayer. As the patrol passed by them, Krystal sighed a breath of relief and looked up at Boone. He hadn't stepped back from her yet. Their eyes locked and suddenly feeling awkward at the closeness she blushed and cleared her throat.
"I think we should go." She said in a whisper.
A slight mischievous glint sparkled in his eyes and his lip turned up into an ever so slight smile in the corners of his mouth. Stepping back and looking down both directions of the hallway, he pulled her from the doorway.
"Yeah, lets find a way out of here before we get our brains tapped."
1111111112111111.title: Close call

choices: find the right sector
guard gets you lost
11111111121111111.content:
Boone kept a tight grip on Krystal's hand as they fled down the long corridor. Just a few more feet and they would be able to launch one of the hydropods and head to the sector where he thought his family might be being held captive.

Krystal was starting to run out of breath when someone grabbed her and her hand jerked away from Boone. She was flung to the floor with force and lay in a heap on the cold stone floor. Boone turned around to see two guards standing over Krystal, with pistols drawn and pointed towards him. At first he thought that she had been knocked out but he saw a slight movement and she blinked her eyes at him.

"Alright, don't shoot.", Boone called to them."Look, here's my weapon, you can have it and I won't give you anymore trouble." He started walking towards them with the gun barrel down.

They were starting to get nervous because he was getting so close to them and they started shouting at him to stop. With all their attention on him, Krystal did a legsweep on one of them and the other looked to see what had happened and Boone was on top of him in a flash. He struck him with the butt of the pistol and knocked him out cold. The other one tried to get to his gun and Krystal stepped on his fingers and kicked the gun out of his reach.

"Don't mess up his fingers too bad, I think we can use his fingerprints to get us into the sector. If he doesn't cooperate, we'll just take his fingers and he can stay."

The guard stood up and looked as if he was more than willing to cooperate.

"Wow Krystal, that legsweep was something else.", he told her.

"Thanks, we novelist watch alot of tv and movies and besides, I've always wanted to try that to see if it works."

"Well it worked great. You, we're heading for the hydropods.", he said to the guard, "Just remember there's a gun pointed at your back."
11111111121111111.title: Hey, it works in the movies

111111111211111111.content:
Krystal and Boone followed the guard closely as they wandered the intricate halls of the compound. The guard led them to a dark corridor with walls of metal. The lights reflected so brightly that they all needed to squint to see.
"Are you sure you are leading us the right way? Because if you aren't we will do worse to you then they can," said Boone jabbing the butt of his gun into the guards back.
"No sir. This is the right way. I've just... I'm not allowed down here. I have only been here to escort a group here once. No one goes down here except the Director..." the guard was babbling nervously as he shuffled down the hall, "except that Alpha group, uh... this is as far as I took them. It was worse then. I mean, I don't know. Maybe it is worse now cuz you have a gun."
Smack! Boone slapped the guard on the back of his head. "Shut up already. Just take us!"
Krystal bit her lip for a couple seconds and then nervously licked her lips. "What goes on down there?"
The guard shrugged his shoulders. He looked cauciously at Boone before hesitantly replying. "Never knew."
"What did the group go down there for? Who were they?"
Boone glanced at Krystal. He didnt want to loose track of the guard for one second. His mind was already thinking. He had never heard of the Alpha group since he worked there, maybe they had added some new groups since he had been there. But before he could finish his thoughts they had arrived at the end of the hall.
Boone looked around. There was no where else to go. Except into the elevator...

ditch the lying guard and hope for the best
111111111211111112.content:
They headed down the corridor with sirens still blasting in their ears. The guard looked from side to side at the numbers and letters on the walls as he lead the way. Boone held the gun in one hand and held on to Krystal's hand in the other.

"That siren is driving me bonkers.", Krystal said trying to speak over it.

"Yeah, me too. I would have thought we would have been at the hydropod pad by now. It's been almost ten minutes. I think this guy is lost and it better not be on purpose."

He stopped the guard and pointed the gun at his face as he pinned him against the wall.

"I'm really not in the mood to play games today, so you'd better quit fooling around, ok?", he said sincerely to the guard.

"No, I'm not, I swear, it's just a little further. Down there." The guard said nervously, sweat running down his forehead and dripping off his nose.

"Alright, get moving.", Boone said as he spun him around and shoved him forward.

1111111112111111121.content:
They finally reached the podpad and not a moment too soon. They knew they were only one step ahead of the swarms of troops sent to kill them. Boone made the guard put his fingers on the pad and give them clearance and the doors whooshed open and they jumped inside. Once inside the hydropod, Boone hit the guard on the head with the gun butt, knocking him out cold and laying him on the floor.

"Why did you do that? We need his prints!", she said, staring at the unconcious man on the floor.

"Not anymore. If you're able to breach the pods, the rest is not secured. We can walk in and take what we want, provided we hurry before they catch up to us." He stood over the control panel for the pod and punched in some numbers. "Lucky for me that I had to come down here once with one of the medical techs and watched him run this gizmo."
He showed her how to program it too and sat down and put his arm around her as it took off, hissing along the metal rail. "As soon as we find everyone, I want you to lead everyone back to the pods and get them loaded and out of here."

"What about you?", she looked into his eyes and knew she may never see him again.

"Don't you worry about me. You can't get rid of me that easy. I've got an idea for those nasty aliens and their buddies. I'm gonna blast them right back to their home planet....without their spaceship!"

He kissed her and held her tight until the doors whooshed open and they peered out into a long tunnel with dim lights on each side. A list above the tunnel directed them to Sector G, just twenty feet ahead on the right. This would be the longest twenty feet they'd ever went, there and back to the pods.

Boone runs into a snag
11111111121111111211.content:
Boone and Krystal took off running. There wasn't a moment to spare. Once in Sector G, they looked up at rows of cells, like the modern day prisons with floors and floors of cells. They came upon the rows of buttons that would release the cell doors and Krystal looked at Boone.

"Which buttons do we push?", she said.

"I don't know.", he sighed. "Since we don't have time to stand around pushing them all...", he pushed her back and fired the gun at the control panel and it sparked and hissed and the cell doors clunked open. People warily poked their heads out the door.

"Listen everyone.",Boone barked loud enough for everyone to hear, "We're getting you out of here, but you have to do it in orderly fashion and as quick as possible."

"Boone, oh Boone, we're so glad to see you're alright. We knew you'd find us if you could!", his mother shouted to him." His father, sister, her husband and little girl were with her waving.

"He waved back and threw them a kiss. This is Krystal and she is going to lead you to the hydropods and get you out of here as fast as possible. I love you guys, see you soon. He planted another kiss on Krystal's lips and she gave him the thumbs up sign.

People were coming down the stairs as Krystal directed them to the pods. She took one last look at Boone before turning to go program the pods and make their escape. She hoped at least one of the pods would have enough time to make it back in time to pick up Boone before the whole place blew up. As she stepped into the pod, she heard a new type of alarm announcing that the entire building would self destruct in T-fifteen minutes.
11111111121111111211.title: Help at last!

have the aliens really fled?
111111111211111112111.content:
Krystal hung on tight as the pods took off. She had jumped into the one with Boone's family at their urging. His mother had smiled and held on to her hand, knowing that there was something special going on between her son and this girl.

All of a sudden there was a jolt, but the pod kept speeding along. Krystal figured it was one of the first sections to blow apart, as they felt the pod vibrate and heard a low rumble. They wouldn't have to worry about the guards chasing them now, they would have heard the self destruct warning and were trying to save their own skins.

The rumbling grew louder, as if it was right behind them. Boone's mother clinched Krystal's hand tighter as they came to a halt. She directed everyone to the front of the building. As they hit the front doors, there was a loud explosion to their right. All they could see was a big cloud of dust headed their way.

"Everyone head for that dry riverbed! Hurry!" She pointed to her left. "Get down in there, now!" She shoved people along now as the gray, swirling dust cloud was about to descend upon them.

As fast as it came, the dustcloud had moved over them and was beginning to settle in the nearby trees.

Boone's father helped his mother from the ground and they coughed and tried to shake the remaining dust from their clothes. His sister and her husband and daughter were just as dusty but fine.
Boone's mother looked at all the faces in the crowd and looked scared.

"What is it mother?", Boone's sister asked, looking alarmed.

"Krystal, where's Krystal?", she yelled through the rumbling of explosions.
111111111211111112111.title: Getting out alive

Boone ran down the empty corridors, his hiking boots slapping loudly on the concrete floor. He had set off three detonators and was close to the last one. He swung open a heavy metal door to his right, Sector C, reading in bold letters across it.

He found the detonator switch on the panel and lifted the protective cover from it and pushed the button. Another warning sounded, telling him he had only fifteen minutes to evacuate the area. Fifteen minutes would be just enough time to get back to the ground floor, which was up, grab a pod and be out the front door before the explosion ripped him apart.
1111111112111111121111.title: Time to spare?

do a jackie chan flip over them
11111111121111111211111.content:
Boone walked quickly, trying to stay calm and not lose his sense of direction. This was not easy with the floor beneath him shaking violently, threating to open up and swallow him at any moment. A couple of times he braced himself against the wall to hold himself steady.

He was close to the stairwell now, the elevators having shutdown after the warnings had started, when he heard what sounded like frustrated jibberish up ahead. He peeked his head around the corner and there were three aliens blocking the hallway and his escape.

The aliens were passing around what looked to be a gameboy, with buttons and flashing lights. They were punching it with their tripod appendages, passing it to another then back again. He felt like this device was somehow their means of escape and something was wrong with it. The tallest of the three finally took the device, took a wire from it's chest area and plugged it in. The device was now making an almost melodic sound and the three stood as if in a trance staring down at it.

Boone looked at his watch, only eleven minutes left. Either the aliens make something happen, or he would have to run right through them to get to the stairs. He would mow them down like bowling pins if need be, hopefully catching them completly off guard and too stunned to stop him.

111111111211111112111111.content:
Boone stood on the other side of the wall waiting, sweat beads pouring down his forehead, settling on his eyebrows and he wiped them away with his hand. Ten minutes and counting. He decided to rush the little suckers, he couldn't wait any longer or he'd be incinerated.

He took in a deep breath and yelling all the way, charged towards them with all he had. They looked up all at once and just as he reached them, they disentegrated before his eyes, in a bluish fog. He slammed into the stairwell door with too much velocity, since he hadn't had the creatures to slow him down, knocking the breath from him when he bounced off the hard floor.

He lay there dazed for a moment and heard the computer countdown on the overhead speaker.

"T minus seven minutes and fifty six seconds."

He rolled over grunting, sucking in air to replenish his empty lungs. He got up, opened the door and drug his body up the stairs. It would take a miracle for him to make it up the flight of stairs and still make it out alive.

He turned around and saw a fireball rushing up the stairs behind him. He reached the doorknob and as he turned it, the explosion blew him into the next room.

He was on the floor with debris all around him. He was covered with dirt and soot and he had a pain in his leg and feared it was broken. He winced when he tried to stand and couldn't. 111111111211111112111111111.content:
The pod flew along the tunnel as the rumbling continued and grew to a deafening roar. Boone wanted to thank her for getting his family out alive, for risking her life to come back for him, and most of all, that he loved her. She couldn't hear him over the roar and put a finger to his lips, she knew everything he wanted to say by the look of gratitude in his eyes. She would do it again, a thousand times, for she loved him equally. She kissed him hard on the lips and the pod slammed to a stop, throwing them up against the far wall of the pod and Boone gasped in pain.

They stood up and looked through the dusty windows, they were still short of the entrance of the building, the last blast had shorted out the pod. Krystal pounded on the door, but it would not open.

"Open that panel over there and pull the wires.", Boone shouted at her.

She ran to the panel grasping at the wires and yanking them. Sparks flew and she backed away with her hand in front of her face. The doors opened and when she took her hand down, a trickle of blood was there from her head.

"You're bleeding from a cut on your head.", Boone told her as he rose to get out.

"That's the least of my worries right now. I've got lots of blood, let's go."

111111111211111112111112.content:
Taking a deep breath, Boone stepped out from behind the corner. The pudgy alien in the middle looked up, stepped back and sounded a guttural alarm. It sounded like the call of a dying orca. With nothing but fear to fuel him, Boone rushed towards the three aliens the way he used to rush the quarterback in varsity football. He kept his head down and elbows out, putting all his strength into his legs.
Upon impact, in one great sweep, the short pudgy alien flew into the wall, smashing its head and spewing dark blue mucus on the ground. The taller one went crashing to the floor, sending the small gadget in its hand scuttling across the cold metallic floor. The third alien received an elbow directly in the neck. It shrieked, and in a quick gesture, Boone punched it square in the face. It’s bone density was so weak that Boone’s large fist went straight through the alien’s face.
Pulling out his fist, Boone shook off the purplish goo from his hand. He felt nauseous for a second, but remembered the tall alien on the floor. Wasting no time, Boone stomped on its head with the heel of his RedWing boot. Thank God they’re waterproof, he thought to himself.
He picked up the small gadget from the floor and began heading for the stairwell. Only one more level to go, he thought, feeling the adrenaline speeding through his heart. The noisy alarm kept blaring, as the sounds of chaos filled his ears.
“NINE MINUTES ‘TIL EXPLOSION,” said the overhead voice.
As he reached the top of level negative one, Boone realized he wasn’t alone. He turned, and what he saw filled him with horror. It was a corridor; it was filled with glass cells, about the size of telephone booths. He walked up to one and his heart was filled with sadness and rage. Inside the booth, was Mr. Calvert, a man he’d known since childhood. He was never a bright man, but he was always kind and warm to Boone’s family, and he knew about harvesting crops and keeping the land fertile. Mr. Calvert was suspended in a clear liquid, possibly water, with tubes inserted into his nose and mouth.
Boone looked into the next cell and saw Mrs. Coolidge, the widow from down the street.
He knew most of the people in this small town, and now he realized that they were here, alive; stored in a dormant state for easy transportation to another planet. Boone knew very well what was going to be of these people.
“SEVEN MINUTES,” announced the beacon voice.
111111111211111112111112.title: 24...36....Hike!

choices: Leave them, there's no time to save them

1111111112111111121111121.content:
“Damn!” yelled Boone kicking one of the booths.
Behind the glass, the shriveled elderly body rocked as the water inside the booth undulated.
He looked at his watch: It read 6:49….48….47….Looking up, he felt his heart drop again. He felt helpless. This situation was helpless. Just get out of here, a voice in his head was telling him. He thought of Krystal; her soft skin; her hair; her beautiful face. Those eyes of hers, so piercing yet so compassionate.
He looked up at Mr. Calvert again, hanging in utero like an unborn fetus, so exposed and helpless.
“I’m getting you out of here Mr. C,” said Boone.
He ran down the corridor, past all the hanging bodies and reached the small panel at the end. On it were buttons and lights and some strange symbols. Boone recognized some of them from the pods downstairs, but most of them were foreign to him.
“Here goes,” he said, pushing a random button.
Nothing happened.
“SIX MINUTES ‘TIL EXPLOSION,” announced the beacon.
He pushed another button. This time, something happened. The people in the chambers began moving. Their legs began kicking and their arms swaying. Suddenly, Boone realized in horror that they were slowly, horribly drowning.
Panic-stricken, he ran back to the small console and pressed another button. Suddenly, all the doors opened, spilling gallons and gallons of thick viscous liquid down the hall. Boone was up to his knees in the thick warm substance. The prisoners, now on the floor, began getting up, bewildered and naked.
Boone ran to Mr. Calvert who looked as disoriented as a tharn rabbit. He couldn’t move, but he spoke a few words, “Johnny,” he said to Boone, “I thought I’d never see you again. Is this heaven?”
“FIVE MINUTES ‘TIL EXPLOSION,” replied the voice on the loudspeakers.
“We have to get out of here!” yelled Boone feeling uncertain about his decision. He knew five minutes was never enough time to get these people out of here, but he couldn’t leave them here to die. Maybe I should’ve left them in these booths, he thought to himself, at least they would have died peacefully and painlessly. It was too late now.
He would have to make a decision.
1111111112111111121111121.title: Awakenings

11111111121111111211111212.content:
Wading in the embryonic fluid, Boone started heading for the door with his hand around Mr. Calvert’s arm. The elderly man stumbled with every step he took. Looking behind him, Boone noticed that the other prisoners were not following him.
“FOUR MINUTES,” announced the voice.
“People,” yelled Boone, “We have to get out of here. In less then four minutes, this place will be a mountain of rubble.”
The elderly people stared at him blankly.
“Is this heaven?” repeated Mr. Calvert.
Frustrated, Boone kicked one of the booths again. He looked down, feeling tears swelling up inside of him, and noticed something. It was the little hand-held device he took from his friends downstairs. This one was much simpler than the console he had just used, it relied mostly on graphics that just needed to be touched with a finger.
He touched the icon resembling the outside of the base. A detailed cross section appeared on the screen. He touched the first level below ground, and a little map of the level he was on appeared. He moved his finger down the corridor, and the camera view followed the direction of his finger. His finger came around the corner, and suddenly, he saw the corridor he was in. Right there in the palm of his hand was a flooded corridor, with a crowd of people standing in it.
“TWO MINUTES,” reminded the voice.
With a stroke of his finger, he highlighted the people on the small screen and dragged them outside of the level, to the surface just outside the building. Somehow, he knew something was going to happen; he knew this was more than a mapping device. He tapped the highlighted people standing outside and everything went black.
Suddenly, Boone found himself outside amongst the trees. The elderly people were there too, naked and trembling. Incredulous, Boone began laughing hysterically but soon remembered it wasn’t over yet.
“ONE MINUTE,” came from the loudspeaker.
“C’mon people,” announced Boone, “follow me as fast as you can.”
Boone heard his voice being called from somewhere in the trees. It was Krystal. He looked up and saw her running towards him with tears streaking down her cheeks. She was bewildered to see the naked people, but realized that they needed help.
“We have to get as far away as possible,” said Krystal.
“I know,“ replied Boone, “I put enough explosives in there to make a crater.”

11112122122.content:
Krystal's eyes fluttered open only to be assaulted by a blinding light. She closed her eyes again. All was silent until she heard someone whisper, "Krystal, welcome to heaven."

If this was heaven, why was it so damn hot?

Cautiously, she opened her eyes. Standing before her was a distinguished looking man graying slightly at the temples wearing a perfectly fitted tux and holding a martini glass with some kind of red liquor, presumably.

"This is heaven?" she asked, captivated by his eyes which were somewhere between gun-metal gray and blue.

"No, I'm just messing with you." He chuckled. "It's hell."

She broke his gaze and glanced around expecting to find all the accoutrements one might expect in hell - fiery pits and such - but found she was in what appeared to be a penthouse apartment. She was lying on a leather sofa which was without a doubt the most comfortable piece of furniture she had ever been on in her life.

"It's a little...luxurious isn't it?" she asked.

"Hey, why should I suffer?" He pointed to a window which took up the entire wall opposite the sofa. "That's their job."

Krystal got up gingerly and walked to the window. Looking down about seven stories she saw something more akin to what she expected, flaming pits and all, but another structure caught her eye. "What's that?" she asked.

The man followed her glance. "Movie theater." He replied.

"You have movies?"

"A few - Gigli, Ishtar. Oh, and anything with Ashton Kutcher. Except for That 70's Show, that was actually not bad."

Krystal shrugged a silent agreement. "No AC?"

"I'm comfortable." He said. "But let's get down to brass tacks. The reason you're here and not down there is that you have an option. You can stay here. Well, not here," he corrected himself gesturing at the penthouse. "But, here in hell. Or you can go back and save that quaint little town of yours from alien invasion."

"You're giving me a choice?" She asked, incredulous.

He laughed. "Believe me, what's about to go down up there may even outdo anything I've come up with in quite some time. It might be fun to watch. Either way, for me it's win - win." He took a sip from his martini. "So what'll it be?"

11211121.content:
Krystal's brow furrowed in disbelief. "The road is quite a while from here, and this is far from the first house you could have come across. If you don't come clean in ten seconds, I'm calling the police." She backed toward the bedroom and the bag in which she kept her small pistol, a KelTech 9mm. She had never had to use it on a person before, and she didn't really want to start.

The stranger took two slow steps forward, into the main room of the cabin. "Lissen, Ma'am. I saw you earlier in town. You're not from here, and you should keep it that way. I'm not trying to scare you off, but if I have to, I will. There's things up here, things that nobody has a right to create and fewer have a right to know about. I'm warning you; if you don't leave now, you may never be able to." His hands raised in a gesture of placation, but Krystal felt anything but calm.

There was something strange about this man, something Krystal couldn't quite put her finger on. The pace of his speech was quite different from that of the people she had chatted with in town, and his face looked a lot less odd than the majority of the countenances that blessed the sleepy town's inhabitants.

"No, you listen. I came here to write and relax and I'm not leaving because the locals think they're the only ones entitled to this corner of the world. I don't want anything to do with your piss-ant little town, your piss-ant little 'things,' whatever they are, or your piss-ant little warnings." Her voice was high-pitched and scratchy, but the feeling of her bottom bumping into the bedroom's doorknob momentarily slowed the trip-hammering of her heart.

As soon as her fingers gripped the cool smoothness of the doorknob, --

Above, a fleet of rolling clouds blotched out the glimmering moon. A chill wind swept down upon the glowering thickets.
The jeep ran over a bump in the gravely road as I scanned the midnight landscape before me, a mere sea of jagged silhouettes. The equipment rattled in the back.
I turned on the radio to let my mind drift to something else. It came on alright. But the sound wasn't. It fizzed and whirred, making me dizzy. It made me so dizzy I didn't notice the road block before me. The world before me blurred and my body become loose like a ragdoll. I fell. And fell. And fell.
'Beeeeeeep! Beeeeeeep!'
In the nick of time I drifted back and the steering wheel lay clearly before me. I used it to maneouvre myself to a halt.
The lights of the jeep lay fixed upon a small group of police officers, approaching my jeep.

"Please me lady, if ya' just turn off the lights!" he hissed, covering up his face.
"Wouldn't it be dark?"
"Dark!!!" He turned his back to the beams of light pouring from the jeep. "Oh yes!"
"No!"
"Sorry?"
"I won't. I need a way out. Is there any other road."
"Nobody escapes. Nobody will!"
The tall man before her slouched down to the ground where he seemed to... change colour? A blue, shimmery colour like an electric-blue.
When it raised itself, I let out a wailing cry.

Thinking back on it now, I remember that they all had the same face. No, that is ridiculous. They all had the same look of threatening desperation and hollowness. Pale, stretched and angry. I drove as quickly as I could back to my lodge.

The lights were on inside. I had turned them off, I am certain of it. I thought I saw a shadow passing the window. Maybe it was Frank or Miss Garfield. Maybe the landlord had come back. But there was a high pitched whine coming from inside and the birds in the forest had stopped singing.

Cautiously, I approached the door and put my key in the lock. No need. The door was slightly open. I gave it a short, quiet push and went inside.

A mystery novel....a mystery novel... where to start. My brilliant idea had vanished, where had it gone. Oh, all this commotion had run me dry. I left my little timber cottage to show my face to the town once more.

I walked briskly down the street to a small cafe called, 'Rockys'. It was a small little shop, looked as though someone had tried to demolish it many times but became exhausted halfway thru and decided not to bother. The little man inside behind the desk was old and badly dressed. He had a gruff voice and even harsher face. "Short black thanks, oh, and a donut if you've got one", I began retrieving my money from my little leather purse when his gruff voice mumbled, "We got coffee and Mama Burne's Danish's, thats all". "That'll do then".

I tried desperatly to bite into the danish but with no result, it was rock hard. What was it about this town? Something was definately fisshy, something I needed to work out.

I looked over to my left to see a little lady with white hair, little gray whiskers from her chin and big wide glasses streaching over her face, there was something about her. I felt as though I knew her straight away. I continued to drink my coffee, but I was sure she had her eyes on me, squinted with a deathly gaze.

I felt extremely uneasy about her. My palms were perspiring and my throat was beginning to feel dry. Vision becoming blurry, it was as if I was about to faint. And the strange thing is...

... this was all perfectly normal to me.

Believe it or not, I'm very timid. I have always been this nervous around other people ever since, well, I could remember!

Perhaps my difficult childhood is the reason why I act like this. During elementary, junior high, and highschool, I was teased a lot because I was one of the most clever students in the school. The students called me mean names like 'Miss Einstein' and 'Teacher's Pet' (I helped them out whenever I could).

I was also taunted at because of my looks. My parents were incredibly strict. Get this-- they never let me put makeup or shave my legs until I was in 9th grade! My peers' mocking hurt me real deep. Despite Mom and Dad's severity, I am still glad that they were as firm as they were back then. Their harshness taught me that beauty came from the inside, not from the outside. I am so glad that I've turned into a gorgeous, beautiful young woman. Now back to the present reality...

I hurriedly gave the small man the expense for my meal, plus a tip.

Throwing my trash away, I ambled out Rockys' door. A warm breeze of fresh, countryside air greeted me as I drifted into the sidewalk.

I gazed around at the little rural town's scenery. Where to go next?

122.content:
Krystal couldn't believe that Beck had given her the cold shoulder. So she decided she better get back to her mystery because her publisher had insisted on a deadline. She said to herself, "I'm such a sissy! What's wrong with a little fog in the air?"
She shrugged her shoulders and started walking towards the house.

She kept walking and walking but couldn't see the house. "I cannot be lost," she said. "I never get lost."

As she was wondering where the house had disappeared into, her foot slipped. She was almost going to fall down but she held onto a tree branch just in time to see that she had come by the side of a lake covered with algae.

She saw the floating form of a corpse mostly hidden by the weeds. She felt a scream rising to her throat but she held her composure.

The corpse opened his eyes and said, "You're the chosen. Nothing dies but this planet may come to pass. Its progress is a myth. It will be grand power versus grand loss. Now you go and let them know. Forget everything else. You have a job to do on a grand scale. I'll lead you on. You're not alone! Now go get to it, go! Now!"

Krystal turned to see if there was anyone else around but the woods seemed empty and the fog had lifted a little. She made out the vague form of the house in the distant. She started running toward it.

As she reached the French doors, she heard her cell phone ring, the sound of which comforted her. She ran upstairs to her desk and picked up the cell phone. As soon as she pushed the button her phone went dead.

"I have to go into town and call the police and the media," she thought.
"No, we won't let you!" A rough husky voice answered her thoughts.

She turned around to the sound of the voice. She saw nothing. She picked up her purse with one hand and held her gun with the other.

She opened her mouth to say, "Who are you?" but no sound could escape from her lips. She frowned at her own shivering. She wasn't the kind to be afraid. Or so she had thought. Yet she knew she couldn't give in. Probably the corpse was right. All this wasn't her imagination as she was suspecting at the back of her mind. She had a job to do. But what?

She decided to get back out again. It will be safer out in the open air she thought. She ran downstairs. She scrambled from door to door, from window to window only to find them shut tight. Someone had welded down everything.

She held her purse in her underarm and pointed the gun in front of her. With her other hand she yanked a lamp off from a side table and hurled it at a window but the glass wouldn't break. She tried to break other windows, other doors. It was of no use. She was caged in.

It started getting dark. Outside a strange wind had started to howl. She heard a crash, then a thunder. As another lightning hit the ground, she saw from the window a huge, gray, eerie and globular aircraft land on the grass. The craft's doors opened and out came some indistinguishable forms.
122.title: Caged in
